the qustion: Which is the MOST appropriate general step when treating resistant hypertension?
c: Add low-dose spironolactone after optimizing diuretic
explanation: Correct: Add low-dose spironolactone after optimizing diuretic. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 144)

the qustion: Which pregnancy-safe agent is correctly paired with a caution?
b: Long-acting nifedipine — avoid due to hypotension risk
d: Methyldopa — avoid due to poor safety profile
explanation: Correct: Labetalol — caution in asthma/heart disease/CHF. In pregnancy use labetalol, methyldopa, or long‑acting nifedipine; avoid ACEi/ARB and IR nifedipine. (Slide p. 160)

the qustion: Which of the following is an indicated reason for specialist referral?
a: Resistant HTN, suspected secondary HTN, or HTN emergency
explanation: Correct: Resistant HTN, suspected secondary HTN, or HTN emergency. Refer for suspected secondary HTN, resistant HTN, or acute emergencies. (Slide p. 163)

the qustion: Which of the following agents/classes is most associated with cough and angioedema?
explanation: Correct: ACE inhibitors. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 78)

the qustion: Which element is part of the DASH-style pattern emphasized on the slide?
c: Fruits, vegetables, whole grains, low-fat dairy
explanation: Correct: Fruits, vegetables, whole grains, low-fat dairy. DASH emphasizes fruits/vegetables, whole grains, and low‑fat dairy; lowers BP without supplements. (Slide p. 62)

the qustion: Which of the following drugs can contribute to secondary hypertension?
explanation: Correct: Oral contraceptives and NSAIDs. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 17)

the qustion: Which combination is a compelling indication pairing for ARBs similar to ACEIs?
explanation: Correct: DM, CKD, LV dysfunction, post-MI. ACEi/ARB are key for CKD, DM, and post‑MI; monitor renal function and potassium. (Slide p. 114)

the qustion: Which is the BEST answer about HBPM protocol timing?
c: Twice daily (morning/evening), duplicate readings, 7 days, discard day 1
explanation: Correct: Twice daily (morning/evening), duplicate readings, 7 days, discard day 1. Home thresholds are lower than clinic; use a structured 7‑day protocol to confirm diagnosis. (Slide p. 41)

the qustion: Which of the following is the BEST lifestyle recommendation to pair with meds in a sedentary, high-sodium diet patient?
d: Adopt DASH diet and increase regular activity
explanation: Correct: Adopt DASH diet and increase regular activity. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 62)

the qustion: Which definition correctly describes hypertensive urgency?
explanation: Correct: >180/120 mmHg without acute end-organ damage. Hypertensive urgency = severe BP without acute end‑organ damage; adjust oral therapy. (Slide p. 147)

the qustion: Which definition correctly describes hypertensive emergency?
explanation: Correct: >180/120 mmHg with acute end-organ damage. Hypertensive emergency = severe BP with acute end‑organ damage; hospital care required. (Slide p. 147)

the qustion: Which is a practical next step when BP remains above goal after appropriate therapy and work-up?
a: Refer to a specialist after ~6 months uncontrolled
explanation: Correct: Refer to a specialist after ~6 months uncontrolled. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 145)

the qustion: Which set of thiazide(-like) examples appears on the slide?
explanation: Correct: Hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone, indapamide. Thiazides are effective first‑line agents; consider chlorthalidone/indapamide for potency. (Slide p. 93)

the qustion: Which patient factor favors initiating thiazide or CCB as first-line (per JNC 8 African American guidance on slide)?
d: History of ACEI cough but CKD present
explanation: Correct: African American ethnicity without CKD/HF. DHP CCBs lower BP via vasodilation; watch for edema and reflex tachycardia. (Slide p. 158)

the qustion: Which screening is reasonable in a patient with suspected primary aldosteronism?
explanation: Correct: Aldosterone-to-renin ratio. Primary aldosteronism screening uses the aldosterone‑to‑renin ratio; think of hypokalemia/resistant HTN. (Slide p. 143)

the qustion: Which is the MOST appropriate reason to choose a loop diuretic over thiazide in HTN management?
explanation: Correct: CKD with volume overload. Thiazides are effective first‑line agents; consider chlorthalidone/indapamide for potency. (Slide p. 144)

the qustion: Which patient characteristic favors an alpha-blocker as add-on therapy?
explanation: Correct: Benign prostatic hyperplasia. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 113)

the qustion: Which adverse effect is most associated with alpha-blockers in hypertension management?
explanation: Correct: Orthostatic hypotension. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 113)

the qustion: Which rhythm indication favors non-dihydropyridine CCBs (when not contraindicated)?
explanation: Correct: Supraventricular tachycardia. Non‑DHP CCBs reduce heart rate/contractility; avoid with beta blockers or AV block/HFrEF. (Slide p. 114)

the qustion: Which comorbidity often cautions against nonselective beta blocker initiation?
explanation: Correct: Asthma with bronchospasm. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 113)

the qustion: Which is an additional ABPM indication listed on the slide besides white-coat/masked HTN?
explanation: Correct: Suspected episodic hypertension. White‑coat HTN = high clinic BP with normal home/ABPM; confirm out of office. (Slide p. 40)

the qustion: Which set includes modifiable risk factors for essential hypertension?
c: Obesity, excess sodium, sedentary lifestyle, alcohol
explanation: Correct: Obesity, excess sodium, sedentary lifestyle, alcohol. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 51)

the qustion: Which out-of-office strategy is RECOMMENDED to confirm diagnosis before treatment per USPSTF?
explanation: Correct: HBPM and/or ABPM. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 30)

the qustion: Which BP pattern warrants out-of-office confirmation or serial office visits according to the slide?
c: Elevated office BP ≥130/80 without target organ damage
explanation: Correct: Elevated office BP ≥130/80 without target organ damage. This reflects the definition/threshold or class effect emphasized on the slide. (Slide p. 34)

the qustion: Which medication class is explicitly listed as contraindicated in pregnancy on the slide?
explanation: Correct: ACE inhibitors/ARBs. In pregnancy use labetalol, methyldopa, or long‑acting nifedipine; avoid ACEi/ARB and IR nifedipine. (Slide p. 114)

the qustion: Which diuretic list contains thiazide(-like) examples shown on the slide?
explanation: Correct: Hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone, indapamide. Thiazides are effective first‑line agents; consider chlorthalidone/indapamide for potency. (Slide p. 93)
